framework.ImageFeatures module

class framework.ImageFeatures.ImageFeatures(img, skel, original_folder)[source]

Bases: object

power_calc(image, kernel)[source]
print_features(print_values=False)[source]
framework.ImageFeatures.boxcount(Z, k)[source]

returns a count of squares of size kxk in which there are both colours (black and white), ie. the sum of numbers in those squares is not 0 or k^2 Z: np.array, matrix to be checked, needs to be 2D k: int, size of a square

framework.ImageFeatures.boxcount_grayscale(Z, k)[source]

find min and max intensity in the box and return their difference Z - np.array, array to find difference in intensities in k - int, size of a box

framework.ImageFeatures.fractal_dimension(Z, threshold=0.9)[source]

calculate fractal dimension of an object in an array defined to be above certain threshold as a count of squares with both black and white pixels for a sequence of square sizes. The dimension is the a coefficient to a poly fit to log(count) vs log(size) as defined in the sources. :param Z: np.array, must be 2D :param threshold: float, a thr to distinguish background from foreground and pick up the shape, originally from (0, 1) for a scaled arr but can be any number, generates boolean array :return: coefficients to the poly fit, fractal dimension of a shape in the given arr

framework.ImageFeatures.fractal_dimension_grayscale(Z)[source]

works the same as fractal_dimension() just does not look at counts and does not require a binary arr rather is looks at intensities (hence can be used for a grayscale image) and returns fractal dimensions D_B and D_M (based on sums and means), as described in https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/plugins/fraclac/FLHelp/Glossary.htm#grayscale :param Z: np. array, must be 2D :return: D_B and D_M fractal dimensions based on polyfit to log(sum) or log(mean) resp. vs log(sizes)

framework.ImageFeatures.fractal_dimension_grayscale_DBC(Z)[source]

Differential box counting method with implementation of appropriate box height selection. :param Z: 2D np.array :return: fd for a grayscale image
